definition: the activity or process of doing scientific experiments
the activity or process of trying or testing new ideas, methods, etc. to find out what effect they have

to recommend somebody/something to somebody
if something commends itself to somebody, they approve of it
to give somebody/something to somebody in order to be taken care of
deserving praise and approval
increasing in regular amounts
the ability to know something by using your feelings rather than considering the facts
an idea or a strong feeling that something is true although you cannot explain why
praise; approval
an award or official statement giving public praise for somebody/something
an expert on something
the process of arranging for somebody outside a company to do work or provide goods for that company
to demand that something happen or that somebody agree to do something
to state clearly that something is true, especially when other people do not believe you
a person who supports and admires a particular person or set of ideas
a person who is very interested in a particular activity and follows all the recent news about it
a person who does things after somebody else has done them first
a person who chooses to regularly receive somebody’s messages using a social media service
lasting for a long time or for all time in the future; existing all the time
to allow a bill, debt, etc. to reach a large total
to make a piece of clothing quickly, especially by sewing
to raise something, especially a flag
to think or believe that something is true or possible (based on the knowledge that you have)
used to make a statement, request or suggestion less direct or less strong
to pretend that something is true; to imagine what would happen if something were true
to be expected or required to do/be something according to a rule, a custom, an arrangement, etc.
to be generally believed or expected to be/do something
to not be allowed to do something
a plant with leaves that taste bitter and are used in salads or in making soup or sauces
the practice of using artificial methods to avoid becoming pregnant when having sex; the methods of doing this
a slight change to or movement of something
the act of getting used to a changed or new situation
a large notice, often with a picture on it, that is put in a public place to advertise something
a large picture that is printed on paper and put on a wall as decoration

a large written or printed notice that is put in a public place or carried on a stick in a march (= a formal walk to protest about something)
to bring two or more people together again after they have been separated for a long time; to come together again
to join together again separate areas or separate groups within an organization, a political party, etc.; to come together again
to encourage somebody to do something violent, illegal or unpleasant, especially by making them angry or excited

that offends or upsets people; that is morally wrong
very bad

to persuade somebody to do something, especially to help you

the act or process of finding new people to join a company, an organization, the armed forces, etc.
the respect and value that somebody/something has because of their social position, or what they have done
great in amount, size, importance, etc.
living on the land or on the ground, rather than in water, in trees or in the air
connected with the planet Earth
operating by using equipment on the surface of the earth, rather than sending the signal via a satellite
the act of being slow to speak or act because you feel uncertain or nervous
the fact of being worried about doing something, especially because you are not sure that it is right or appropriate

a slight shaking movement in a part of your body caused, for example, by cold or fear
food put on a hook to catch fish or in nets, traps, etc. to catch animals or birds

a person who pays to receive a service
a person who gives money regularly to help the work of an organization such as a charity
used to describe marks such as accents, placed over, under or through a letter in some languages, to show that the letter should be pronounced in a different way from the same letter without a mark
an amount of money that you pay regularly to receive a service, be a member of a club, support a charity or receive regular copies of a newspaper or magazine; the act of paying this money
the act of people paying money for something to be done
considered by society to be acceptable, good or correct
fairly good; that there is no reason to be ashamed of
following immediately one after the other
